POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Favourite Words
POST.MESSAGE: I never had the inclination (another word I like) to read that book or go see the movie...it's not really the type of genre I particularly am into...

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Favourite Words
POST.MESSAGE: Maudlin is a great word, too. For some reason, I used to think that it meant tacky, or gawdy so I sometimes stuble over its meaning still.

POST.SUBJECT: Words du Jour
POST.MESSAGE:
Antiquarian (one who knows antiques) This is a beautiful word with a nice syllabic rhythm. Ive also come to realize that the more vowels there are in the word, the more varied the word can be pronounced. The Q does that too.

Magnanimous (generous) I heard Kevin Newman use this word to describe Barack Obama earlier today, and it totally threw me off guard. Im not too sure if I had heard it before, but the curious sounding of it really piqued my interest and I looked into it. Its my newest favourite word.

Congenital (inherited) Even though the word starts with con, and its typically used in a negative context, I find that it has a very happy sound to it. Each individual syllable sounds rather harsh, but together it makes a really melodic word.

Ramshackle (run-down) This is one of the greatest words to read or say. It sounds like gibberish, and it sounds like a positive word. But ramshackle is used to denote something old and decrepit.

Battle-ax The informal use of the word, as we use it in society now, is in regards to a nagging woman. But neither battle nor ax has anything to do with nagging, yet its a great word and evokes great imagery. For me, its of a female Viking swinging a flail. Dont ask why.

Flummoxed (perplexed) This is a very happy sounding word. And its a bouncy sounding work. Its a smooth word to say because of the bounce.

Mosaic (collage, design) This is a creatively evocative word for me. Im not sure why, but mosaic creates beautiful coloured imagery in my mind of elaborate tiled artwork. It also reminds me of the tile game of the same name that came with Windows 95.

Shuck (remove husk from) This is the ugliest word I can think of, and I have thought this for a while. The sh and uck sounds clash so harsh, it just combines to make an ugly sounding word. But out of this ugliness, it becomes one of my favourites.

Diaphragm (contraceptive, muscle under ribcage) I think its the spelling that really attracts me to this word. The ph and the agm make it a very unusual looking word. But its a nice word to say, and despite the odd-looking spelling, it is s a very smooth word in speech.

Schedule The only reason I have this on my list is because this is one of many words that society allows to have drastically different pronunciations, and people are cool with that. And it bothers me. Schedule sounds like sked-jewel, not shed-jul.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Words du Jour
POST.MESSAGE:
With congenital, I worry that I will mix it up -- or the reader will mix it up -- with congenial, or the other way around. Those are tricky words.
Shuck is a great onomatopoeic word, and it has many good companions:
From Moby Thesaurus II by Grady Ward, 1.0 [moby-thesaurus]:
19 Moby Thesaurus words for "shuck": bark, bran, capsule, case, chaff, corn shuck, cornhusk, decorticate, hull, husk, jacket, palea, peel, pod, rind, shell, skin, slough, strip
Flummoxed is good too. It's the word that I recommended to the students at Poppy Secondary a couple of weeks ago as a great choice to use on their Provincial exam essays as a verbal descriptor.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Words du Jour
POST.MESSAGE: Shuck is also the word for opening an oyster. I have fond memories of watching the guy behind the bar at Bozo's (http://blog.nola.com/anguslind/2008/04/bozo_turns_90.html) shuck oysters, and eating them by the half dozen (in months whose names contain the letter R) since I was about 5 or 6. Once, I insisted we take the oyster shells home, so my mother helped me wash them in the bathroom and we took them home. :)

POST.SUBJECT: my word list
POST.MESSAGE:
These are a few words that I have found recently while reading. I like them because they are either visually interesting or have good meanings.


Ascetic- dedicates their life to a pursuit of contemplative ideals (visually interesting word)

Diaphanous- very sheer and light almost transparent.( this is an all round nice word- and it's nice to say)

Somnambulist- sleepwalking (this was a new word I found and liked what it meant)

Inveterate- settled into a habit, practice,or feeling (This one appeals visually to me)

flourish- to be in a vigorous state (I like saying this word it sounds nice in your mouth)

Equivocate- using ambiguous or unclear expressions to avoid commitment or to mislead ( visually interesting)

Sycophantic- attempts to win favor through flattery ( just fun to say)

Intangible- incapable of being perceived by the senses ( i like the meaning of this word)

Plume- a large showy feather ( another newer word to me)

Enchant(ment)- to impart a magic quality or effect ( just a pretty word)

Benevolence- desire to do good to others ( I like the meaning of this word)

Conviction- an unshakable belief in something without need for proof or evidence ( I like the strength in this word)

Credence- belief as to the truth of something ( a neat word all around)

Humongous- extraordinarily large (sounds funny- I like that)

Enraptured- delight beyond measure ( a good visual word)

Sentient- having the power of perception by the senses ( another new word for me that I liked in the end)

POST.SUBJECT: Re: my word list
POST.MESSAGE: Those are some resonant words! Look how many of them have multiple vowel sounds. All of them, in fact. This tells us something about the power of vowels, and the reason that the meditative utterance Om is actually all the vowels together -- A E I O U Um. As you may remember from IDEA class, the Egyptians thought that vowels were the key to all magic.

POST.SUBJECT: Bamboozling words!
POST.MESSAGE:
You guys sure do know some interesting words! Here are a few simpler ones as well:

strike
flat
turn
amble
far
dwell
path
horizon
shell
rumble
tumble
arc
sweep
clear
tap
simmer
umber
walk
tear
morning
twilight

POST.SUBJECT: Best Words
POST.MESSAGE:
Fecund - Producing or capable of producing offspring, fruit, vegetation, etc. in abundance

Pellucid - Allowing the maximum passage of light, as glass - translucent

Castigate - To criticize or reprimand severely

Ubiquitous - Existing or being everywhere at the same time, omnipresent

Slattern - A slovenly, untidy woman or girl

Languid - Lacking in vigor or vitality, slack or slow

Vital - Of or pertaining to life

Augment - To make larger, enlarge in size, number, or strength

Temerity - Reckless boldness, rashness

Effeminate - Having traits, tastes, or habits that are traditionally considered female

Amorphous - Lacking definite form, having no specific shape

Putrescence - Becoming putrid or undergoing putrefication

Turgid - Swollen or distended

Brackish - Having a salty or briny flavour

Pedantic - Ostentatious in one's learning, or overly concerned with minute details and formalisms

Torpid - Inactive or sluggish

I was reading D.H. Lawrence's "The Rainbow" for one of my classes, and I found most of these words within the novel. I fell quite in love with each of these words - my book has big circles and markings in the margins wherever Lawrence used them. His particular favorite seemed to be "Fecund" - that would be the defining trait of one of his characters.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Best Words
POST.MESSAGE:
Pellucid -- I'd forgotten about that word. It's a good one. Fecund, too. Languid is one I tend to over-use.
Yes, Lawrence is great with language. So many of the early 20th century writers were masters and mistresses of the rhythms and treasures of language. It's not something we see much of anymore, which is a great loss to our craft. Though see Chris Hedges, or William Langewiesche, of Sharon Olds. They preserve the thread.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Best Words
POST.MESSAGE: I should definetely check out those writers. I love words, and I find that today the tendency in writing is to over-simplify. A handful of complex, well-placed words in a sentence is always a nice addition.

POST.SUBJECT: My Words Choices
POST.MESSAGE:
I have chosen some of the common words that I always use and come across.


Identity - the distinguishing character or personality of an individual

Ethnic - common racial, national, tribal, religious, linguistic, or cultural origin or background

contradictory - a proposition so related to another that if either of the two is true the other is false and if either is false the other must be true

critique - an act of criticizing

mobilize - to put into movement or circulation

diversity - differing from one another

confidence - a feeling or consciousness of one's powers or of reliance on one's circumstances

ideologies - a systematic body of concepts especially about human life or culture

elaborate - marked by complexity, fullness of detail, or ornateness

passion - intense, driving, or overmastering feeling or conviction

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Words Choices
POST.MESSAGE: Excellent, simple choices. These words are resonant for our times. Identity and Ethnic are especially powerful, as is Ideologies. It's interesting how much of our language preferences derive from our own personal backgrounds.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Words Choices
POST.MESSAGE: I tend to like the words that can be expand to more things or ideas. I can make connection from one thing to another.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Words Choices
POST.MESSAGE: I'd have to say, these are big ticket words for this time period. You know, like "proactive" is a big word in business, or was anyways - words like "ethnic" and "identity" are huge now.

POST.SUBJECT: My Best Words
POST.MESSAGE:
Confabulate to chat
Logorrhoea excessive taking
Agrestic rude, uncultured coarse
Synchronicity - the relation that exists when events occur at the same time; simultaneity; synchronism.
Anomie - social instability resulting from a breakdown of standards and values.
Lascivious - reflecting or producing sexual desire or behavior
Fug - an odorous emanation, especially, the stuffy atmosphere of a poorly ventilated space
Aeneous - brassy or golden green in color
Kloof - a deep glen; ravine
Humbug - something made or done to cheat or deceive
Swink - something made or done to cheat or deceive

Most words that I find interesting are words that just sort of roll of your tongue. Words usually with more than one syllable or that give more meaning and richness to the sentence. For example, for my first word how much more richness does it give to the sentence when you say to confabulate, then to chat.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Best Words
POST.MESSAGE: Confabulate is great, as is synchronicity. A multi-leveled word. Fug and kloof are good, too. Rough and clear words, even if you don't know what they mean!

POST.SUBJECT: Words
POST.MESSAGE:
synecdoche
disciple
perfector
asphalt
defiant
phantasm
alexithymia - (without words for emotions)
revolver
reckoner - (basically an accountant)
crimson

Some of the words I love because of the double meanings they represent. For example - disciple and perfector are religious words used to describe God and the followers of Christ. On the flip side they're also used in Slayer lyrics. The last 5 on the list just have a good resonance when they roll off my tongue. Reckoner is probably my favorite word of this second though because it just sounds badass. It sounds like the name on an antagonist in an old western that wears all black, when in reality it means an accountant.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Words
POST.MESSAGE:
All hail the Crimson King, as they say (or, at least, as Stephen King says). Crimson in a powerful word. Phantasm is great too, as is synecdoche.
Revolver is much better than gun, as is pistol.

POST.SUBJECT: Favourite Words
POST.MESSAGE:
Leaf

Stringent

Grim

Molecular

Credence

Homunculus

Snow

Riposte

Wolf

They aren't fancy or obscure but they are my favourite words, at least the ones I can think of at the moment.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Favourite Words
POST.MESSAGE:
Yay for wolf!

I used to go by the online pseudonym Wolfish (Wolf-ish, meaning wolf-like, not Wolf-fish, which is a big ugly fish).

wolfish is a really good word. I'd forgotten about that one.

POST.SUBJECT: coolest words i know
POST.MESSAGE:
Agitate to disturb or excite emotionally (Although I dont think I would use this word to describe an emotional excitement perse)

Ignobly of low character, of low quality; inferior. A few weeks ago I came across this word as I was reading an essay for an English class and it was the first time I had ever heard it. Still trying to find a way to work it into my writing.

Snoop to prowl or pry; to go about in a sneaking or prying way. I love the word and how it sounds.

Hinge - a jointed device or flexible piece on which a door, gate, shutter, lid, or other attached part turns, swings, or moves.

Jubilation - a feeling of or the expression of joy or exultation.

Concubine - a woman who cohabits with a man to whom she is not legally married, especially one regarded as socially or sexually subservient; mistress. I took a class that focused on Southeast Asian cultures and societies and I kept hearing the word over and over again. I hate that it doesnt have a positive connotation.

Apocalypse - a prophetic revelation, especially concerning a cataclysm in which the forces of good permanently triumph over the forces of evil.

Defenestrate - to throw out of a window. Such a complicated word for such a simple action.

Paradigm - a set of forms all of which contain a particular element, especially the set of all inflected forms based on a single stem or theme.

Doppelganger - a ghostly double or counterpart of a living person. Scary thought, cool word.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: coolest words i know
POST.MESSAGE: Oh, defenestration is a great word, with a great etymology (it literally means "out of the window").

POST.SUBJECT: My Choice Words
POST.MESSAGE:
I noticed that on a lot of the posts that others have submitted for this assignment contain some of the most peculiar words that aren't very common in everyday writing - or at least not my writing. Anyway, rather than continuing with this trend and looking for the words that stand out the most, I decided to go with some of my favourite words that I see on a regular basis (or at least most of them).

Enjoy =)

Exquisite: of such beauty or delicacy as to arouse intense delight

I commonly hear this word in movies and it is a common occurrence in a lot of romantic stories (such as Twilight). Whenever I see this word come up, it immediately brings about an image of a beautiful diamond ring or some sort of high-end jewelry.

Mortifying: to cause or experience shame, humiliation or a wounded pride

Seeing as how I am into a lot of horror and mystery screenwrites, this word can pretty much sum up most gory films in our present time.

Marshmallow: a light, spongy, very sweet confection made of corn syrup, gelatin, sugar and starch and dusted with powder sugar

While walking through Metrotown tonight, I came across a new Rocky Road chocolate store that just opened up near the food court. They just so happened to be selling caramel covered marshmallows on a stick. For some odd reason I just kept reading the word "marshmallow" over and over again, thinking "how the heck did the creator of this food come up with the name marshmallow?"... any ideas?

Chestershire Cat: a fictional cat with a broad fixed smile on its face

Alice in Wonderland is an instant classic for most kids growing up in the late 1980's... how can you not love this word?

Duplex: A house divided into two living units or residences, usually having separate entrances

Supercalafragalisticexpialadocious: Fantastic, very wonderful

Do I even need to explain where this word comes from and why it's so great? Here is a fun fact though, when doing a search on the Online Dictionary website, this word doesn't exist in their database - weird.

Flatulence: The presence of excessive gas in the digestive tract

Treacherous: Marked by unforeseen hazards; dangerous or deceptive.

Bedazzled: To dazzle so completely as to make blind

When I was a kid, I used to have one of those ghetto Bedazzeler machines that you could order over the phone from a infomercial hot line. Ever since then, I would always refer to really busy clothing items as being very "bedazzled" (ex: Ed Hardy products are soooooo bedazzled!)

Agoraphobia: The fear of going out into public places. It can occur with or without panic attacks.

I once read a book based on all the different phobias that have been diagnosed by psychologists. When I read this word I thought to myself "wow... how can these people go on living their lives like this?" I just can't imagine.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: My Choice Words
POST.MESSAGE:
I agree about the slant toward complexity. Some of the best words are indeed commonplace, and this is a good list of them.

Chestershire is Cheshire. You're thinking of Worcestershire, which is pronounced Worster.

POST.SUBJECT: Top-10 words
POST.MESSAGE:
Fun assignment!

Here are mine:

kerf - a slit or notch made by a saw or cutting torch.

naff - unstylish, clichd, or outmoded. 2: to fool around or go about. Naff off - rude imperative. There used to be a UK clothing brand by the name of Naf Naf, not sure if there was a connection.

gribble - a small marine isopod crustacean that destroys submerged timber. I love this word, and the fact that there is a lifeform whose sole purpose is to destroy submerged timber.

wallydrag - a feeble, dwarfed animal or person.

craven - If you were frustrated by a person's cowardly ways, you might want to use the adjective craven to describe their actions. Like this as it's so similar to brazen, which means the opposite.

halcyon - Something that is halcyon is calm, peaceful, or tranquil.

polyglot - Someone who is able to speak, write, or read several languages is a polyglot. Again, fun to say.

aegis -To act under the aegis of someone is to act with their protection, support, or guardianship.

philistine - A philistine is a person who is disdainful of intellectual or artistic pursuits. A word that sounds like what it describes...

bon vivant- A bon vivant is a person who is devoted to the finer things in life, especially good food and drink. And usually fun to hang out with!

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Top-10 words
POST.MESSAGE:
Halcyon is the title of a song from the mortal kombat soundtrack and it matches that description very well.

It's also the name of these super powered balls of elemental destruction in final fantasy video games. Peaceful, unless you are near them, then it is death and maiming and resetting the game.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Top-10 words
POST.MESSAGE: I remember trying to get some Gnome Halcyon in FFXII...I can't recall any of their uses, but they were frustrating to obtain.

DISCUSSION.NAME: i hope there's no repeats about

POST.SUBJECT: i hope there's no repeats about
POST.MESSAGE:
These are the words I love saying, writing them out longhand is just as fun.

snorgle
ribbon
erlkonig
maim
textual poachers
peche (pe-CHAY) sin, not the peach
quire a stack of papers
puddle-wonderful
jeer
fourmillante ant infested, but like a city

POST.SUBJECT: Re: i hope there's no repeats about
POST.MESSAGE: I've never heard of some of these (snorgle, erlkonig, fourmillante). Language is a deep well.

POST.SUBJECT: Words
POST.MESSAGE:
anomaly - something different, abnormal, peculiar, or not easily classified.

inevitable - unavoidable.

elixir - a substance held capable of changing base metals into gold; a substance held capable of prolonging life indefinitely.

evanescent - tending to vanish like vapor; transient.

effervescent - to show liveliness or exhilaration.

ridiculous - arousing or deserving ridicule; absurd; preposterous.

redundant - exceeding what is necessary or normal .

atonement - reparation for an offense or injury; reconciliation.

ethereal - of or relating to the regions beyond the earth; celestial.

chrysanthemum - a flower!

myriad - a great number.

vagabond - moving from place to place without a fixed home.

elegy - moving from place to place without a fixed home.

I like words that are pleasant to say and to hear. None of these words are too complex to not be understood in the context of a sentence. They offer a more interesting way to speak about something simple.=

POST.SUBJECT: Re: Words
POST.MESSAGE: evanescent is such a beautiful descriptive word...I haven't used it in a long time, thanks for reminding me about this one!

DISCUSSION.NAME: 10 words that will make you a better person

POST.SUBJECT: 10 words that will make you a better person
POST.MESSAGE:
Codswallop - Means 'nonsense' in Britain, I remember my grandma using it once and I found it to be an amazing word.

Legume - Just a fun word to say.

Liquescent - Means melty.

Synonymous - Fun to use.

Eclectic - Again, fun to use, fun to say.

Celluloid - Not many uses for it, but a fantastic word nonetheless.

Terse - Rhymes with verse, purse, curse.

Sluice - A word that flows quite well...

Pandemonium - Severely underused word.

Prelude - An introduction. Also the type of car I have.

POST.SUBJECT: Re: 10 words that will make you a better person
POST.MESSAGE: haha I'm going to try to use "Codswallop" on my boyfriend and see the look of confusion on his face! Cool word!

POST.SUBJECT: Re: 10 words that will make you a better person
POST.MESSAGE:
Haha I use the word "legume" all the time...I believe its a french word for vegetable actually!

Sluice is a fabulous word too. Glad you reminded me.

2) Efferevescent: Light, airy, happy, all that good stuff, with a dash of myth

clusterf*#k
